Multiple data can be provided via
as a list of datasets of potentially different length ([*x0*,
, ...]), or as a 2D ndarray in which each column is a dataset.  Note that the ndarray form is transposed relative to the list form.
Masked arrays are not supported.
The
, and
parameters behave as in
numpy.histogram
For large numbers of bins (>1000), 'step' and 'stepfilled' can be significantly faster than 'bar' and 'barstacked'.
If given, the following parameters also accept a string
, which is interpreted as
(unless this raises an exception):
~matplotlib.patches.Patch
properties
Input values, this takes either a single array or a sequence of arrays which are not required to be of the same length.
If
is an integer, it defines the number of equal-width bins in the range.
If

is a sequence, it defines the bin edges, including the left edge of the first bin and the right edge of the last bin; in this case, bins may be unequally spaced.  All but the last (righthand-most) bin is half-open.  In other words, if
is:
then the first bin is
(including 1, but excluding 2) and the second
.  The last bin, however, is
, which
If
is a string, it is one of the binning strategies supported by
numpy.histogram_bin_edges
: 'auto', 'fd', 'doane', 'scott', 'stone', 'rice', 'sturges', or 'sqrt'.

children.type_: int or sequence or str, default: :rc:`hist.bins`

data.value: The lower and upper range of the bins. Lower and upper outliers are ignored. If not provided,
is
. Range has no effect if
is a sequence.
If

If
, draw and return a probability density: each bin will display the bin's raw count divided by the total number of counts
), so that the area under the histogram integrates to 1 (
If

An array of weights, of the same shape as
.  Each value in
only contributes its associated weight towards the bin count (instead of 1).  If
is
, the weights are normalized, so that the integral of the density over the range remains 1.
This parameter can be used to draw a histogram of data that has already been binned, e.g. using
numpy.histogram
(by treating each bin as a single point with a weight equal to its count) :

counts, bins = np.histogram(data)
plt.hist(bins[:-1], bins, weights=counts)
(or you may alternatively use
~.bar()
If
, then a histogram is computed where each bin gives the counts in that bin plus all bins for smaller values. The last bin gives the total number of datapoints.
If
is also
then the histogram is normalized such that the last bin equals 1.
If
is a number less than 0 (e.g., -1), the direction of accumulation is reversed.  In this case, if
is also
, then the histogram is normalized such that the first bin equals 1.
Location of the bottom of each bin, ie. bins are drawn from
to
If a scalar, the bottom of each bin is shifted by the same amount. If an array, each bin is shifted independently and the length of bottom must match the number of bins. If None, defaults to 0.

children.type_: array-like, scalar, or None, default: None

data.value: The type of histogram to draw.
'bar' is a traditional bar-type histogram.  If multiple data   are given the bars are arranged side by side.
'barstacked' is a bar-type histogram where multiple   data are stacked on top of each other.
'step' generates a lineplot that is by default unfilled.
'stepfilled' generates a lineplot that is by default filled.
The horizontal alignment of the histogram bars.
'left': bars are centered on the left bin edges.
'mid': bars are centered between the bin edges.
'right': bars are centered on the right bin edges.
If 'horizontal',
~.Axes.barh
will be used for bar-type histograms and the
kwarg will be the left edges.
The relative width of the bars as a fraction of the bin width.  If
, automatically compute the width.
Ignored if
is 'step' or 'stepfilled'.
If
, the histogram axis will be set to a log scale.
Color or sequence of colors, one per dataset.  Default (
) uses the standard line color sequence.

children.type_: color or array-like of colors or None, default: None

data.value: String, or sequence of strings to match multiple datasets.  Bar charts yield multiple patches per dataset, but only the first gets the label, so that
~.Axes.legend
will work as expected.
If
, multiple data are stacked on top of each other If
multiple data are arranged side by side if histtype is 'bar' or on top of each other if histtype is 'step'
The values of the histogram bins. See
and
for a description of the possible semantics.  If input
is an array, then this is an array of length
. If input is a sequence of arrays
, then this is a list of arrays with the values of the histograms for each of the arrays in the same order.  The dtype of the array
(or of its element arrays) will always be float even if no weighting or normalization is used.
The edges of the bins. Length nbins + 1 (nbins left edges and right edge of last bin).  Always a single array even when multiple data sets are passed in.
Container of individual artists used to create the histogram or list of such containers if there are multiple input datasets.

children.type_: `.BarContainer` or list of a single `.Polygon` or list of such objects

data.value: Plot a histogram.
2D histogram with rectangular bins
2D histogram with hexagonal bins
